content.webTitle: Review: Selective Memory: An Autobiography by Katharine Whitehorn

fields.headline: Selective Memory: An Autobiography
fields.bodyText: A true inspiration, Katharine Whitehorn has not only lived through some of the most transformative times for women, but helped shape them for the better. Her first boyfriend at Cambridge requested she leave university to marry him and become a receptionist. She ditched him and, after a galvanising stint on Woman's Own, joined The Observer, where she dispensed her sparky satire on careers and having it all for 36 years. This lively autobiography is a joy to read, skipping along in Whitehorn's jolly-hockey-sticks tone, where things are either 'super' or 'grotty' and everyone is 'great buddies'. The usual journalism anecdotes abound, alongside tales of not-quite domestic bliss with late husband Gavin Lyall and sons Bernard and Jake. Now aged 80 and still writing, Whitehorn is as relevant and witty as ever.
